content.description: Start by mantling onto what's left of the broken block and follow the corner to a balancy crux up high. Fun with thoughtful movement.
content.location: In the middle of the cliff, just left of the short finger crack 2nd & Main. The route starts at a big broken block lying on the ground.

content.description: This has fun, techy climbing with a great crux. It was named after Jim Gilchrist's response after climbing the route.
content.location:
This is just right of "

The Technician

". It shares a start with "

Mado Skates

" then heads left.

content.description: This is a fantastic route that is very appropriately named.  Climbs through a loose roof band down low (stick clip), and then up the very hard to decipher left-facing dihedral system above.  Watch for fragile holds and a few large, loose flakes up high.
content.location: To be filled/edited in.

content.description: Begin on the left side of the offwidth at the large flake in the corner.  Either climb directly or stem up and step over, follow the corner to the top.
content.protection: 6 bolts, and some trad gear for the bottom.
content.location: This is on the Laser Beam Wall, about 6 routes in from the left.

content.description:
This is a sport, hybrid pitch. Start on "

Entropy

" then finish on "

Flying Zapato

". It is a good warm-up for other routes nearby.
content.location:
Start on "

Entropy

."

content.description: This is the traddiest sport climb I may have ever done.  There is lots of chimneying, stemming, and mantling on this one!  According to the guide, you can cut left before the last bolt at the top and clip the anchors of "The Now" thereby keeping the grade to 10d, but you'd be missing out on the full-value chimney above.
content.location: On the upper end of The Skillet; it's the route starting just to the right of "The Now".

content.description: Climb a blunt arete with fun, technical moves. It was named after sharp hold in the route's crux.
content.location:
Use the same start as "

Angry Angler

," but stay on the arete.

content.description: Climb the crack in the obvious corner.  It packs a lot of fun into its short length.  The anchors are made out of webbing and weren't in the greatest condition in the 2012 season.
content.protection:
Small, to "3 gear.

Per

Vaughn

: there is a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the second to last route on the right side of the Laser Beam Wall.

content.description: This is one of the Frying Pan's best moderates. It has great rock and is well-protected.
content.location:
Climb a right-facing corner left of "

Sharp Edge

".

content.description: Fun, slab climbing; technical, powerful and thought-provoking.
content.location:
Start with "

Throwing For Jesus

" then bust up and right.

content.description:
Start on the arete just left of '

Thunder Fairy

'.  Do some technical, balancy moves and arete slapping past the first 4 bolts and then join

Thunder Fairy's

crux for the last 3 bolts.
content.location:
Look for the obvious arete to the left of '

Thunder Fairy

' and '2nd and Main.'

content.description: Start on the arete and pull gleefully straight up until it is clear to trend left (bolt 3) along a left trending seam that turns vertical. If you have tugged through this section and feel like patting yourself on the back (it is kinda hard up to this point), you may want to consider benching your patting hand until you have dispensed with the next 20'.... I thought the crux was the series of moves from the 4th bolt to the 5th. really, really fun climbing!!! Bolted perfectly...the only way this could get another star is if it were 500' longer!!!
content.location: Directly atop the tiered walk around (toward the upper end of the cliff proper) locate a BEAUTIFUL green face. This route is just a couple routes past the striking and obvious arete of Yellowjacket (open project!!!).

content.description: This was the first rock route established at the Skillet. Somewhat tricky climbing leads up to a getting-out-of-the-pool mantle at the chains.
content.protection: Bolts + an optional #0.75 Camalot between the first and second bolts.
content.location:
This is just to the left of

Black Eyes and Spam

, in the middle of the Skillet.

content.description:
This is a slopey and technically demanding route that climbs a stunning black and white streaked face and arete.

Start by liebacking up a wide crack to reach the first bolt.  Move up and right towards the arete using slopey edges until you can slap around the arete and escape to easier terrian out left.  From the ledge, traverse right towards the arete.  With nothing but a right-facing arete and minimal feet, fight your body's urge to barn door off the wall, and precariously reach an atrociously slopey shelf.  A few more horrendously slopey moves gains a huge jug.  But wait, it's not over, the crux awaits.  Using a very awkward undercling, stand up on the jug, and commit to more disappointingly slopey edges on the steep black headwall that leads to the chains.

This route has amazing and unique movement, but it was covered in a fine layer of sand.  Hence, only three stars.  So, if you plan on trying it, bring a brush.  As for the grade, 13a seems like a serious sandbag.  I wouldn't argue if someone called it 13c.  Either way, this thing is a masterpiece.
content.protection: Bolts and a two bolt anchor.  Bring a brush!
content.location: Look for the obvious black and white streaked wall.

content.description: Pumpy, sport pitch!
content.location:
This is left of "

Snag

". A good way to access this route is climb "

Entropy

" or "

Snag

" and lower to the ledge where you can start the route.

content.description:
Climb a mossy slab left of "

Nose Job

". Then move up and right to thin crack. It has a bouldery crux! It is a good idea to clip your belayer into a protection bolt on the ledge.
content.location:
Climb the slab left of "

Nose Job

."

content.description: This is on the right side of the west face of the Chubby Pickle. It is the obvious (and much harder than it looks!) bolted face. I would recommend for a cam (0.75 - 1.5) between the 1st and 2nd bolts in the hollow flake. The climbing is easy, but a slip would result in a grounder. The climbing on the arete proper (bolts 3 - 4) is GREAT and defines off angle & off balance! Great climb!
content.protection: 5 bolts (and a supplementary cam.?.) to chain anchor.
content.location: Find a (chubby) pickle....

content.description:
Climb the first pitch via stemming up the corner and good incut holds. This pitch checks in at 5.10c and has its own anchor at the ledge. This is an enjoyable pitch in its own right.

Above the anchor of that first pitch is a gem of a face climb, with a pronounced crux at the 2nd or 3rd bolt, checking in at 5.11b. Finish with great climbing on the arete and some huge bucket hauling to the upper anchor. The bolts are generously spaced out up high and it's possible to bring some small to medium sized cams but it's also pretty easy terrain.

If you do this climb with one rope, tie a knot in the end of the rope and have some slings handy, because it's a stretch with a 70 meter rope to get down and will entail belayer and climber going up to the first bolt to make it happen.
content.protection: 13 bolts according to the book but seems like more. Long slings helpful when linking the two pitches.
content.location: On the left side of the Skillet is a nose feature. On the right side of that nose is Nose Job, a 10b climbing an open corner. On the left side of that nose is this route, The Camel head, climbing another corner feature, although this corner is more of a 90 degree corner, on darker rock.

climbs.name: Black Eyes and Spam
climbs.fa: Matt Samet, Kasey Cordell, BJ Sbarra, Luke Laeser, June 2005

content.description: Climb up weird dihedrals past two bolts and a few gear placements. The second bolt is clipped from a ledge and "protects" the crux move up into a lieback/stem. Why this bolt wasn't placed two feet higher, and why the hangers were spray painted after they were installed, I'm not sure. Edit: Route was bolted on lead, so OK. Interesting movement and fun climb.
content.protection: Single set of cams and two draws.
content.location: To be filled/edited in.

content.description:
P1. Start with steep, bolted face, then head right on ledge for a left-facing corner. Fun, powerful, mixed crux. Anchor up and left, 5.11a.

P2. Traverse right pull through bulge, then climb techy slab, 5.11a.

P3. Climb up through huge roof wondering if you're in the Gunks, 5.11c/d.

The pitches can be linked, but the rope drag is crazy.  It is possible to rap from top with 70 meter rope. Watch the ends!
content.location:
This is the first route left of "

The Technician

." It is a big, left-facing corner.
